sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville judge John L. Draper., conducted on two dates in November 1980 by Malcolm McKinney as part of the Century III Nashville: Nashville Heritage Project. Draper, who served Nashville as a magistrate (1929-1937), General Sessions Judge (1937-1960), and Criminal Court Judge (1960-1982), discusses the chores he had a child growing up on his family's farm in Goodlettsville during the early 1900s. His chores included feeding the livestock and milking the cows. The complete interview is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: Excerpts from an oral history interview with Nashvillian Annie Woodfolk Carter, conducted on 28 July 1980 by Nathaniel A. Crippens as part of the Century III Nashville: Nashville Heritage Project. In these excerpts, Carter discusses moving to Cleveland, Ohio, during World War I because of new job opportunities for African Americans; African American and Irish neighborhoods in East Nashville when she was a child; the fire department in East Nashville; how she and her husband became affiliated with a predominantly-white Lutheran church after moving back to Nashville during the 1960s; going to Union Station on Sunday afternoons; and the segregated facilities at Union Station and on the trains. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division.

Matthew Kennedy discussing coming to Fisk University after graduating from Julliard; his earliest memories of performing as a child; the bombing of Z. Alexander Looby's home in Nashville; Diane Nash's confrontation with Mayor Ben West; and Nashville sit-ins. Kennedy also talks about the experience he and his wife had being turned away from Morrison's Cafeteria in Nashville, as well as his reaction to the assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr. The complete interview as well as an index is available in the Special Collections Division.

sourceResource.description: Excerpts from an oral history interview with Mary Diane Maynard Ross, conducted on 2 Oct. 2006 by Linda Barnickel as part of the Nashville Public Library's Veterans History Project. Ross discusses the difficulty of leaving behind her young daughter when she was deployed to the Persian Gulf during Operation Desert Shield; her concern about her daughter viewing television news, and the emotional impact of receiving a letter from her daughter written in cursive, which meant she was a "big girl" now; the type of uniform and clothing worn during her service in the Persian Gulf; the steps she took before she was sent overseas to prepare herself for her duties as a medic, the likelihood of losing one of her own soldiers, and what it was like when that happened, including coping strategies both at the time and since then; what it was like upon her return from overseas, including her pride in serving with the 101st Airborne (Air Assault) Division and being awarded the Combat Medics Badge - one of very few women to receive this honor; and being dropped with her platoon on an airstrip in Iraq during Operation Desert Storm, surrounded by Bedouins, and without any infantry support whatsoever. The complete interview is available in the repository.
relation: Veterans History Project: Persian Gulf War series

sourceResource.description: An edited excerpt with transcript and photograph from an interview with Martin Brady, conducted on 19 September 2007 by Deanna Larson at the Nashville StoryCorps StoryBooth, located in the Nashville Room of the Nashville Public Library. Brady shares memories of his father's literary career, including his collaborations with Walter Kerr. Out of Leo Brady's many works, Martin describes two plays (Yankee Doodle Boy, a play based on the life of George M. Cohan; Brother Orchid, based on a short story), a Broadway musical revue (Count Me In), and four novels (Edge of Doom, which was made into a movie by Samuel Goldwyn; Signs and Wonders; The Quiet Gun; and The Love Tap). The complete, un-edited interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division. These interviews were recorded by StoryCorps at the Nashville Public Library with the support of the Nashville Public Library Foundation and are provided courtesy of StoryCorps, a national initiative of Sound Portraits Productions to record and collect oral history interviews. www.storycorps.net

sourceResource.description: Excerpts from the reminiscences of Roy C. Avery, recorded in June 1971 by Catherine Berry Pilcher Avery and Rev. William Dixon Gray. The recording is part of the Century III Nashville: Nashville Heritage Project. Avery recalls the boredom and routine of everyday life in the Army during World War I; sailing across the Atlantic Ocean for service in France on board the Cunard ship Olympic; and getting promoted to first lieutenant and having to have his new uniform made by a French tailor, with humorous results. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division. The complete interview, as well as a complete transcript and Avery's World War I diary, is available online via the Library of Congress Veterans History Project at http://lcweb2.loc.gov/diglib/vhp/story/loc.natlib.afc2001001.00436/.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville educator Mildred Owsley Buchanan., conducted on two dates in November 1980 by Paul Clements as part of the Century III Nashville: Nashville Heritage Project. Buchanan, a home economics teacher in Nashville city schools from the late 1920s through ca. 1963, discusses having multiple generations of her family living with her throughout her life. She explains that it was a common practice to have older relatives living in one's household and that it was not common for people to be sent to nursing homes. The complete interview is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville veteran James Carlew, conducted on 25 March 2004 by Larry Patterson as part of the Nashville Public Library's Veterans History Project. Carlew, who served in the Navy during World War II and in the Army in the Korean War, discusses his experiences in basic training at Fort Jackson, South Carolina, as he entered Army service during the Korean War. He provides vivid descriptions of his training including obstacle courses, being in a trench while a tank crossed above him, and shells exploding and machine guns firing nearby. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: This is an interview with Ann Geary and Mary Kay Tolleson. Both women were long time members of the Memphis Catholic Council on Human Relations and among the few white persons who participated in the march. This interview took place in the home of Poppy Karchmer two days after the "mini-riot" that followed the break-up of the march led by Martin Luther King, Jr. on MArch 28, 1968. Geary and Tolleson had been discussing their experiences on that day when Mrs. Karchmer asked if she might record their remarks. Mrs. Karchmer, later a member of the Memphis Search for Meaning Committee, donated this take to the committee's collection. This is the only interview in the collection which pre-dates the assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr. From the Mississippi Valley Collection, collected by the Memphis Search for Meaning Committee from 1968-1973.
relation: University of Memphis Mississippi Valley Collection

sourceResource.description: Audio files of Dickson County residents Howard Deal, Margaret Deal, and Earlie Deal recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. They describe opening their family sorghum mill in White Bluff in 1921. The step-by-step process of sorghum and molassas making is explained. The Deal's share family history and the challenges of running a sorghum mill. They also touch on field hollers or karo-ing, whistling, farming practices, livestock, and music.

sourceResource.description: Sixteen excerpts from an oral history interview with Nashville businessman Douglas B. Havron, conducted on 4 April 2007 by James T. Havron as part of the Nashville Public Library's Nashville Business Leaders Oral History Project. In these clips Havron discusses his early aspiration to become the director of marketing for the Ford Motor Company; witnessing the Challenger disaster; his experience working for Angelo Formosa Food Manufacturers Inc., a family-owned produce supplier in Nashville, Tennessee; his impression of the menu and management at the original Houston's restaurant in West End; the quality assurance practices he witnessed while working as a prep cook for Houston's restaurant; carrying over the weekly white bean soup and corn cake tradition from Nero's to Green Hills Grille; Robert Orr's purchase of the original Maxwell House coffee recipe and equipment; his decision to become a local restaurant owner; the circumstances leading up to his purchase of Sam & Zoe's, a local coffee shop located in the Berry Hill community; the growth, success and expansion possibilities associated with Sam and Zoe's; the evolution of his personal definition of success and how it relates to family; characteristics of local business men in Nashville; the importance of competition and location for business owners specifically pertaining to development in the Berry Hill community; his personal management style; and the general public's perceived difference between corporate-operated and privately-owned business. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division.
relation: Nashville Business Leaders Oral History Project

sourceResource.description: Audio excerpt of Jewel Allen oral history recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. He discusses how he used to bottom chairs during the winters while his wife pieced quilts. His wife taught him to piece quilts and she learned to bottom chairs. They fixed chairs in Carter, Mississippi; Collierville, Tennessee; and Memphis, Tennessee. He stopped working on chairs and took a job as a janitor at Allen White School after his wife died.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville lawyer and judge Alfred Thompson Adams, conducted on 16 September 1980 by Leanne Thornton as part of the Historic Nashville, Inc. Oral History Project. Adams, who served Nashville as Chancellor of Part Two of the Davidson County Chancery Court from 1957 to 1970, discusses traveling to Beersheba Springs during the summers. He also discusses the history of Beersheba Springs, which was incorporated by the Tennessee General Assembly and recognized as a summer resort in 1839. The Beersheba Springs Historic District was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1980. The complete interview is available in the repository.

Marshall shares memories from his Korean War service, including checking fishing boats for mines and how one of his sailors who was originally supposed to be discharged from the military saved the lives of everyone on his ship. The complete, un-edited interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division. sourceResource.description: Excerpts from an interview with civil rights movement participant King M. Hollands, conducted on 28 June 2006 by Larry Patterson as part of the Nashville Public Library's Civil Rights Oral History Project. Hollands was one of the first students to desegregate Father Ryan High School in Nashville, Tennessee, the first school in Nashville to integrate in 1954. Hollands was also a student activist during the Nashville sit-in movement of the 1960s. In the excerpts, Hollands discusses the social environment and school integration at Father Ryan High School; the atmosphere of camaraderie in jail upon arrest during the Nashville sit-in movement; the parents' support of the jailed activists; and his personal values of being a civil rights movement participant. The complete interview is available in the Special Collections Division.

creator: Interview conducted by Wayne Moore, recording made by Greg Yates.
sourceResource.description: Hobart Parrish describing what attracted him to join the Civilian Conservation Corps. He could get an education, earn money, and learn a trade. It was difficult to go to college, and he felt he would get the same preparation in the Civilian Conservation Corps taking their training in various trades. He also felt that if he did want to go to college he would be able to save money he made and could afford it. He also comments on the amounts of pay he received in Civilian Conservation Corps, how much he was given and how much the Civilian Conservation Corps sent home to his family.

Carlew was the oldest of eleven children. In addition to a desire to serve his country, one of his motivations for enlisting was to help support his family. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: The third episode of the Memphis Room Music Show, hosted by Eldon "Chip" Holliday. In this episode, Chip discusses the melting pot of Memphis' musical history and how it gave rise to one of the all-time great jazz pianists: Phineas Newborn Jr. Though little known today outside of jazz circles, in his prime Newborn was frequently compared to Art Tatum and Bud Powell while also being acknowledged as one of the most talented musicians working and recording.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville educator Mildred Owsley Buchanan., conducted on two dates in November 1980 by Paul Clements as part of the Century III Nashville: Nashville Heritage Project. Buchanan, a home economics teacher in Nashville city schools from the late 1920s through ca. 1963, discusses her family's meals when she was growing up. She explains that they had two hot meals a day--breakfast and lunch--and that supper consisted of leftovers or bread and milk. The complete interview is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: This is an interview with William B. Ingram who was former mayor of Memphis (1964-68) during last term of City Commission, succeeded by Mayor Henry Loeb and new City Council form of government on January 1, 1968. As a fighter pilot during the second World War, Ingram was shot down over Belgium and was prisoner in Germany for 13 months. He attended Southwestern-at-Memphis and Southern Law University and also was appointed judge of City Court in 1957. From the Mississippi Valley Collection, collected by the Memphis Search for Meaning Committee from 1968-1973.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville educator Mildred Owsley Buchanan., conducted on two dates in November 1980 by Paul Clements as part of the Century III Nashville: Nashville Heritage Project. Buchanan, a home economics teacher in Nashville city schools from the late 1920s through ca. 1963, discusses changes that occurred in the city schools at about the same time that she started teaching, particularly allowing married women to teach and allowing six-year-olds to attend school. She also discusses what the first day of school was like when she began teaching. The complete interview is available in the repository.

creator: Interview conducted by Wayne Moore, recording made by Greg Yates.
sourceResource.description: Parrish recalls that no Civilian Conservation Corps workers he knew of ever got into trouble while he was in the camp. He states they didn't always behave, but they never got caught. There was an officer in Clarksville who wanted to catch men from the Civilian Conservation Corps camp misbehaving. There was a bootlegger that supplied them with whiskey and the officer tried to catch Civilian Conservation Corps boys going there but never had any luck. Also comments on how camps enforced their own rules and policed themselves. Comments on different denominations of churches.
relation: Hobart Parrish Oral Histories

creator: Kiely, Denis
sourceResource.description: Bledsoe County resident Johnson Swafford describes homemade instruments such as hide and cheese box banjos, gourd fiddles, and the mouth bow. Swafford makes banjos, fiddles, dulcimers, and mandolins, and he relates his processes. Swafford remembers shape-note singing schools in the area, where songs were sung a cappella, and the schools would end with a revival. He talks of candy pulls, ice cream socials, buck dancing, square dancing, and logging activities that fostered community spirit.

The complete interview, as well as a transcript, is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: The money made by the Civilian Conservation Corps could be spent by the family and it would help the towns that it went to. A butchershop owner once told Parrish if it hadn't been for Civilian Conservation Corps money he would've had to close. It helped the Civilian Conservation Corps families, the shop owners, and the towns. Boys in the camps learned a trade and the ones that played music or had comedic talent performed in the camps. While on the Mississippi River doing flood control, one worker drowned; that is the only fatality from his camp he is aware of.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville educator Mildred Owsley Buchanan., conducted on two dates in November 1980 by Paul Clements as part of the Century III Nashville: Nashville Heritage Project. Buchanan, a home economics teacher in Nashville city schools from the late 1920s through ca. 1963, discusses the Buttermilk Ridge area of Nashville on Lebanon Road where she grew up. This area was home to several dairies, which is how the area got its name. The complete interview is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Andromedia "Andy" Bagwell Noel, conducted on 1 November 2004 by Betty Richards as part of the Nashville Public Library's Veterans History Project. Noel served from 1943 until 1946 as a Gray Lady at Thayer Veterans Hospital on White Bridge Road in Nashville, Tennessee. In this excerpt, Noel discusses her duties as a Gray Lady. The Gray Ladies were a volunteer organization founded by the American National Red Cross (later American Red Cross) in 1918 to provide non-medical assistance to military hospitals. This was later expanded to include all hospitals. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the repository.

creator: Interview conducted by Wayne Moore, recording made by Greg Yates.
sourceResource.description: Hobart Parrish describing how aware he was of the conditions in the Great Depression and the New Deal. He saw pictures from New York or Pittsburgh of people in soup lines. In his area they were unable to sell produce but mostly raised their own food. They only had to buy certain items (like salt and black pepper) from peddling wagons. The Depression made it difficult to make money, but didn't impact rural areas in the same manner as it did in the towns.
relation: Hobart Parrish Oral Histories

creator: Allen, Ray
sourceResource.description: Audio files of Fentress County resident Porter Linder recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Tales of Stearns Logging illustrate the commercial logging that came to the Big South Fork area between 1900 and 1920. The logging camps, logging trains, and large-scale operations of Michigan-based Stearns Coal and Lumber Company are conveyed. Linder speaks of the tragic 1933 lumber camp shooting sparked by Jerome Boyatt that rocked the Big South Fork area and resulted in five deaths.
relation: Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project Collection, 1979-1984

sourceResource.description: Hobart Parrish talking about joining the Civilian Conservation Corps. He speaks about recruitment site at Bethel College and not being old enough to join the Civilian Conservation Corps, so his birthday was changed from 1917 to 1916 to make him a year older and allow him to join the Civilian Conservation Corps a year earlier than he should have. He took a train to Montgomery County and was encamped at Clarksville, Tennessee.

sourceResource.description: Excerpts from an oral history interview with Angelo Anderson and his daughter Angela Anderson Jones, conducted on 21 Oct. 1986 by John Egerton as part of the Century III Nashville: Nashville Heritage Project. Anderson and Jones discuss Anderson's immigration to the United States from Greece in 1901 and his experiences upon arrival in the U.S.; Anderson's conscription into the Greek army while on a visit back home in 1912; Anderson's buying his uncle's shoeshine business in 1905; other Greek families in Nashville; Anderson's witnessing the Cooper-Carmack shooting in 1908; Anderson's business experiences in Nashville, including operating Candyland; Greek traditions that continued in the United States, including "fixed" marriages and membership in the Greek Orthodox Church; and Anderson's wine making during Prohibition. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division.

sourceResource.description: Excerpts from an oral history interview with Marion F. "Sonny" Smith, conducted on 25 Sept. 2007 by Larry Patterson as part of the Nashville Public Library's Veterans History Project. Smith served with the 503rd Parachute Infantry Regiment of the 173rd Airborne Brigade (Separate) during the Vietnam War. Smith discusses his first jump training as a paratrooper; his arrival at Bien Hoa airbase in South Vietnam in 1966, where he witnessed American coffins being loaded on airplanes for shipment home; ambush training, including use of Claymore mines, booby traps, trip flares, and an anti-intrusion device; an incident when they were ambushed, a sergeant was shot during his effort to aid Smith, and the next group sent on patrol was named Operation Revenge in honor of the wounded sergeant; and an especially close call when his company was pinned down by a sniper in the jungle. The complete interview is available in the repository.
relation: Veterans History Project: Vietnam War series

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville veteran James Carlew, conducted on 25 March 2004 by Larry Patterson as part of the Nashville Public Library's Veterans History Project. Carlew, who served in the Navy during World War II and in the Army in the Korean War discusses his first duty overseas in the Navy during World War II, when he was just 16 years old. Although initially excited, he protested to his commanding officer that he was too young. His first assignment was to bury Japanese dead on Okinawa. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: Parrish's camp was constructed outside the city limits at the time, but would be inside the city limits today. They could walk to town and go to movies. He also attended night school at Clarksville High School, which was permitted in the Civilian Conservation Corps. Some Civilian Conservation Corps men went to Austin Peay as well. He also took courses given at the camp, such as engineering, soil conservation, mechanics, blacksmithing, or forestry. He mostly took engineering classes. Civilian Conservation Corps leaders also taught crews about how to prevent erosion.

He also discusses the First Presbyterian Church being converted into a hospital by Union forces during the Civil War. The complete interview is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: Audio files of Wilson County resident Dick Huddleston's oral history recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville business and civic leader Kenneth L. Roberts, conducted on 27 July 2006 by Cabot Pyle as part of the Nashville Public Library's Nashville Business Leaders Oral History Project: The Turner Interviews. Roberts outlines his theory that today's Nashville is a result of five things that happened during the 1960s. He discusses the first of these events, which was the sit-in movement. He also discusses civil rights leaders involved in the movement in Nashville, including John Lewis, Kelly Miller Smith, and Stokely Carmichael. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Catherine Berry Pilcher Avery, conducted on the 09 February 1981 and the 13 February 1981 by Leanne Thornton as part of the Historic Nashville, Inc. Oral History Project. Avery, the great-granddaughter of early Nashville bookstore owner William Tyler Berry and member of the Ladies Hermitage Association, discusses how her aunt, Betsy Bryan Dorris, was involved in the Ladies Hermitage Association. Betsy was married to Duncan R. Dorris, brother of George Preston Dorris, inventor and manufacturer of the Dorris Car. Avery discusses how George P. Dorris came to build the first car in Nashville at his brother's bicycle shop in 1895 and went on to manufacture cars in St. Louis, Missouri, with first the St. Louis Motor Carriage Company and then the Dorris Motor Car Company. The complete interview is available in the repository.
relation: Historic Nashville, Inc. Oral History Project

Wilson shares his vision of the church in a perfect world; his opinion as to why there is not more diversity in churches; and some ideas for and obstacles in the way of uniting people. The complete, un-edited interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division. These interviews were recorded by StoryCorps at the Nashville Public Library with the support of the Nashville Public Library Foundation and are provided courtesy of StoryCorps, a national initiative of Sound Portraits Productions to record and collect oral history interviews. www.storycorps.net

sourceResource.description: Parrish states that the Tennessee Valley Authority had 40 camps, such as the ones at Pickwick and Norris Dam. Pickwick was built by Civilian Conservation Corps, but the camp was operated by the Tennessee Valley Authority. They did work the Tennessee Valley Authority needed done rather than the soil conservation work they did in regular Civilian Conservation Corps camps. Tennessee Valley Authority camps had a Tennessee Valley Authority number and an army number that stayed with them when they changed locations as long as they continued to do the same work.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from a press conference with former Nashville Mayor Beverly Briley conducted in 1970. Mayor Briley discusses upcoming trip to Washington where he will testify regarding intergovernmental relations and public improvements. Specifically, he addresses the weak provisions of the Interstate Road Program for relocating the residences and businesses associated with the "I-40 situation." Other topics include equal employment opportunity, crime prevention, and the investigation of a book burning incident. The record also contains audio from two budget committee meetings. Audio record is of poor quality, therefore the speech is slurred. The complete record is available at the Metro Government Archives.

sourceResource.description: Excerpts from an oral history interview with Nashville business and civic leader E.W. "Bud" Wendell, conducted on 22 June 2007 by Cabot Pyle as part of the Nashville Public Library's Nashville Business Leaders Oral History Project: The Turner Interviews. In the excerpts, Wendell discusses his early career as a Shield Man with National Life and Accident Life Insurance and how the Grand Ole Opry was a promotional sales tool in the community; the clear channel radio station WSM; upheaval in the Opry family and an exodus of entertainers circa the late 1950s; the origin of the moniker "Music City USA"; and the variety of WSM radio programming that included classical music, an on-air topical program scripted by Bill Williams with Barbara Moore, Teddy Bart, and Larry Munson and presentations to audiences at the churches of Mr. Craig and Mr. Wills; the necessity for the Grand Ole Opry's move from the Ryman Auditorium; and Irving Waugh's creative idea for the development of Opryland. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division.

sourceResource.description: From the Mississippi Valley Collection, collected by the Memphis Search for Meaning Committee from 1968-1973. This is an interview with Maxine Smith. She was one of those invited to have dinner with Dr. King on April 4, 1968. Smith was Executive Secretary of Memphis branch of N.A.A.C.P. and long-time worker in civil rights struggle in Memphis. As a native Memphian, Smith was also active in support of strikers and handled complaints of inequities and mistreatment from black citizens throughout crisis period.
relation: University of Memphis Mississippi Valley Collection

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Wilbur Foster Creighton, Jr., conducted on 18 August 1976 by Ann Wells as part of the Historic Nashville, Inc. Tennessee Centennial Project: Oral History. Creighton discusses the pediments of both Nashville's first Parthenon replica, built for the Tennessee Centennial Exposition of 1897, and second Parthenon replica, opened to the public in 1931, and the debate over the accuracy of the architects' reconstruction of one of the pediments from historical sources. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the repository.

The complete, un-edited interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division. sourceResource.description: This is an interview with Charles Dinkins who was active with several institutions in the 1950s to 1970s. The interviewer was Thomas Faist from MIFA. Cook Oral History Collection on Civil Rights and were made available to the Crossroads to Freedom Digital Archive through a partnership with the Memphis Public Library. The transcripts represent what was said in the interview to the best of our ability. It is possible that some words, particularly names, have been misspelled. We have made no attempt to correct mistakes in grammar.

contributor: Faist, Thomas
sourceResource.description: Interview of Mr. Coby Smith. Interviewed by Thomas Faist. It is part of the Civil Rights Oral History Collection at the Memphis Public Library and Information Center. Mr. Coby Smith is a graduate of Southwestern at Memphis. He was a founding member of the activist group The Invaders. He was a local activist in Memphis during the Sanitation Strike of 1968. Mr. Smith discusses the environment of Memphis during this time and how is organization worked and perceived by others. He also discussed his militant groups interaction with the non-violent civil rights organizations. This interview was done in 1983 for the Everett R. Cook Oral History Collection on Civil Rights. This interview was made available to the Crossroads to Freedom Digital Archive through a partnership with the Memphis Public Library. The transcripts represent what was said in the interview to the best of our ability. It is possible that some words, particularly names, have been misspelled. We have made no attempt to correct mistakes in grammar.

sourceResource.description: An edited excerpt with transcript and photograph from an interview with retired educator A. Laidye Askew, conducted on 26 September 2007 by StoryCorps Facilitator Martha O'Brien at the Nashville StoryCorps StoryBooth, located in the Nashville Room of the Nashville Public Library. Askew shares her philosophy of education, including her use of the Socratic Method; having an open, relaxed atmosphere in the classroom where children have the freedom to do their work when they are ready; and developing visual vocabulary books to help children learn definitions. The complete, un-edited interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division. These interviews were recorded by StoryCorps at the Nashville Public Library with the support of the Nashville Public Library Foundation and are provided courtesy of StoryCorps, a national initiative of Sound Portraits Productions to record and collect oral history interviews. www.storycorps.net

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Andromedia "Andy" Bagwell Noel, conducted on 1 November 2004 by Betty Richards as part of the Nashville Public Library's Veterans History Project. Noel served from 1943 until 1946 as a Gray Lady at Thayer Veterans Hospital on White Bridge Road in Nashville, Tennessee In this excerpt, Noel explains that she joined the Gray Ladies, a volunteer organization founded by American National Red Cross in 1918 to provide non-medical assistance to military hospitals, because the Red Cross had been so helpful to her in getting information about her husband, who was being held as a prisoner of war (POW) in Germany. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: Parrish states that he believes when the Civilian Conservation Corps first ecamped outside Clarksville the locals were a taken aback by their presence, but after a while they became accepted, and locals even provided them lunch. They eventually became a soil conservation service camp. Their original camp number, SCS8, reflects this. The camp's forestry number had been P63 when they were a forestry camp. Camps were numbered according to the kind of work the camp specialized in.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville veteran James Carlew, conducted on 25 March 2004 by Larry Patterson as part of the Nashville Public Library's Veterans History Project. Carlew, who served in the Navy during World War II and in the Army in the Korean War, discusses his experience as the youngest man in his company, at age 15. His fellow sailors had some fun at his expense, challenging him to smoke a cigar, after which he promptly became sick. They also looked out for him, nicknaming him "Young Blood." The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the repository.

Ingram who was former mayor of Memphis (1964-68) during last term of City Commission, succeeded by Mayor Henry Loeb and new City Council form of government on January 1, 1968. As a fighter pilot during the second World War, Ingram was shot down over Belgium and was prisoner in Germany for 13 months. He attended Southwestern-at-Memphis and Southern Law University and also was appointed judge of City Court in 1957. From the Mississippi Valley Collection, collected by the Memphis Search for Meaning Committee from 1968-1973.
relation: University of Memphis Mississippi Valley Collection
sourceResource.rights: Digital Audio (c) 2013, University of Memphis Libraries Preservation and Special Collections Department. All rights reserved. Use of this audio shall be governed by the University of Memphis Libraries
title: Interview with William B. Ingram - Part 3 of 3

sourceResource.description: Audio files of White County neighbors Linnie Johnson and Jesse Robinson, both born in Dekalb County, recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Anecdotes concerning the Ku Klux Klan and Night Riders are included.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Joseph R. O'Donnell, conducted on 7 July 2003 by Robert P. Richardson as part of the Nashville Public Library's Veterans History Project. After his separation from service as a Marine photographer in the late 1940s, he worked for the United States Information Agency (USIA) as the White House photographer, and he kept a photographic record of his association with five US presidents - Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson, and Nixon. In this excerpt, O'Donnell discusses taking a famous photograph of John-John (John Kennedy, Jr.) saluting his father's casket. The complete interview, as well as a transcript, is available in the repository.

creator: Kiely, Denis
sourceResource.description: Bledsoe County resident Johnson Swafford describes homemade instruments such as hide and cheese box banjos, gourd fiddles, and the mouth bow. Swafford makes banjos, fiddles, dulcimers, and mandolins, and he relates his processes. Swafford remembers shape-note singing schools in the area, where songs were sung a cappella, and the schools would end with a revival. He talks of candy pulls, ice cream socials, buck dancing, square dancing, and logging activities that fostered community spirit.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville lawyer and judge Alfred Thompson Adams, conducted on 16 September 1980 by Leanne Thornton as part of the Historic Nashville, Inc. Oral History Project. Adams, who served Nashville as Chancellor of Part Two of the Davidson County Chancery Court from 1957 to 1970, discusses a bet he made with his brother in 1910. His brother bet him half of the pigeons they owned together that he would not run from their house at 1603 Broad Street (now Broadway Avenue) to Vanderbilt and back in his night clothes. Alfred won the bet. The complete interview is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: Upon enlisting in the Civilian Conservation Corps you're supposed to stay 6 months, and most stayed 6 months. They were supposed to discharge a camp member after 2 years. Because of the work he was doing and his position as Civilian Conservation Corps camp assistant, which was a civil service job, he was able to stay in for five years. During his civil service he no longer stayed at the camp but worked there and was still in the Civilian Conservation Corps. Also comments that some individuals, like Frank Sinatra, stayed briefly in the Civilian Conservation Corps and left due to lack of interest.
relation: Hobart Parrish Oral Histories

sourceResource.description: Excerpts from an interview with architectural historian John Kiser, conducted on 10 April 1978 by Deborah Cooney as part of the Historic Nashville Inc. Oral History project. The interview took place in John Kisers' historic home, the Hays-Kiser house, located at 834 Reeves Road in Antioch, Tennessee. In 1974, the house was placed on the National Register. Designated a Davidson County historic landmark in 1989, it is also known as "Locust Hill," with Benjamin D. Wills cited as the original builder circa 1805. Kiser discusses the history of the Hays-Kiser house and how it was known in the Antioch community as the "North Carolina" house; the 18th-century methods used in its construction and anecdotal evidence regarding a 1795 document that described the building of the house; his research in the Court House records documenting the numerous purchases and sales of land by Charles Hays; early records about Hays' service in the Grand Jury; other families living near the Hays; the name "Antioch" and Mr. Hays' donating land for the building of the Antioch Baptist Church; Mrs. Hays' obituary; what happened to the house upon the death of Mr. Hays; and the elaborate interior features of the historic structure. The complete interview, as well as an index and transcript, is available in the Special Collections Division.
relation: Historic Nashville Inc. Oral History Project

sourceResource.description: Oral history excerpts from an oral history interview with Nashville businessman, former State Representative for the 53rd District, civic leader and Davidson County, Tennessee Clerk John H. Arriola, Jr., conducted on 05 June 2007 by James T. Havron as part of the Nashville Business Leaders Oral History Project. In the excerpts, Arriola discusses growing up in Nashville; attending Fall Elementary School; his family's history in small business; his mother's experience in the service industry; the Powers' family fish market; his college business education at the University of Tennessee at Martin; participation in a unique internship opportunity and how it turned into a job in the healthcare industry; the startup of Norman Couser's Country Cooking and the "meat and three" style menu; the decline in locally grown produce as a result of urbanization; his parents' significant role and pride in the family business; how the business will stay in the family and how both immediate and extended family are involved in upkeep and improvement; and Arriola's advice about starting a business in the service industry, emphasizing time commitment. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division.
relation: Nashville Business Leaders Oral History Project

sourceResource.description: Excerpts from an interview with Madison businessman Douglas G. Odom, Jr., conducted on 05 June 2007 by James T. Havron as part of the Nashville Business Leaders Oral History Project. In the excerpts, Odom discusses his family's business, Odom's Tennessee Pride Sausage, including the role his mother, Louise Odom, played in the businesses' success; his service in the Marine Corps; how his grandfather and father got started in the meat industry; how his father started the sausage business with a loan from Henry Powell, a family friend; the involvement of his entire family in the business; the company's involvement with the American Meat Institute; the creation of the trademark farm boy icon; how the company has focused its advertising over the years; the success of Odom's Tennessee Pride Sausage as a small business; the strength of his business competitors; his mother's role as crew chief for the sausage wrappers; and the role copyright has played in protecting the company's trademark. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division.

sourceResource.description: Excerpts from an oral history interview with Nashville engineer Wilbur Foster Creighton, Jr., conducted on 13 December 1980 by Susan Cox as part of the Century III Nashville: Nashville Heritage Project. In these excerpts, Creighton discusses the East Nashville Fire of 1916; his grandfather R.M. Dudley, his home at Pioneer Spring, and how he would help his grandfather stock Shelby and Centennial Lakes; his grandfather Creighton's ownership of Rockwood Stone Quarry in Alabama and how it was taken over by the government during World War I; Foster & Creighton Company, the company co-founded by his grandfather Robert T. Creighton; and some of Foster & Creighton's early jobs, including the Parthenon, Union Station, and the Sparkman and Shelby Street Bridges. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division.

sourceResource.description: Excerpts from an interview with civil rights movement participant Robert "Bobby" Cain, Jr., and his wife, Margo Cain, conducted on 13 June 2007 by Gwen Smith. Cain, one of the "Clinton 12," was the first African-American student to graduate from an integrated public high school in the South, in the late spring of 1957 at Clinton High School in Anderson County, Tennessee. In the excerpts, Cain discusses the mood of the community prior to his first day of school during the desegregation of Clinton High School in 1956-1957; the violent mob attack on Reverend Paul Turner after escorting the twelve students to school; and the Green McAdoo Cultural Center. Margo Cain discusses two media sources about her husband as well as talking about her grandmother's introduction to him when they were students at Tennessee State University. The complete interview is available in the Special Collections Division.
relation: Civil Rights Oral History Project

He discusses how this affected him throughout his life and ministry. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: This is an interview with Arthur Crowns. Crowns was a professor of Sociology with emphasis on law enforcement education at Memphis State University and working to set up programs with Memphis Policement Department. A veteran of World War II, Crowns obtained JD degree in 1950 at the University of Wisconsin. He also earned advanced degree in law enforcement education at Florida State and came to Memphis State in 1967 to head law enforcement degree program in the sociology department. From the Mississippi Valley Collection, collected by the Memphis Search for Meaning Committee from 1968-1973.

Also comments on how camps were assigned and which parks were worked on by the numerous Civilian Conservation Corps camps in Tennessee.

sourceResource.description: Numerous topics related to Memphis are discussed during an episode of Weekend Edition, an NPR program. Starts with a journalist's persepctive on the state of the city. A story about the election of Willie Herenton includes the voices of community members calling in to local radio shows. Hampton Sides covers the new Pyramid. A reporter visits A. Schwab's store on Beale and speaks with proprietor Abe Schwab. A visit to Lucius Burch's Wolf River Society for the Prevention of Taking Oneself Too Seriously. A visit to Graceland. The brothers of the Eric Gales Band -- Manuel Gales (aka "Little Jimmy King"), Eric Gales and Eugene Gales -- record at Ardent Studios. Recorded off of WKNO, there are a few breaks in the original recording.

sourceResource.description: Audio files of Wilson County resident Dick Huddleston's oral history recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. Huddleston, the first park ranger of Cedars of Lebanon State Park, speaks of various homesteads that eventually became part of the park.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Joseph R. O'Donnell, conducted on 7 July 2003 by Robert P. Richardson as part of the Nashville Public Library's Veterans History Project. After his separation from service as a Marine photographer in the late 1940s, he worked for the United States Information Agency (USIA) as the White House photographer, and he kept a photographic record of his association with five US presidents - Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson, and Nixon. In this excerpt, O'Donnell discusses a humorous incident involving Eleanor Roosevelt. The complete interview, as well as a transcript, is available in the repository.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville veteran James Carlew, conducted on 25 March 2004 by Larry Patterson as part of the Nashville Public Library's Veterans History Project. Carlew, who served in the Navy during World War II and in the Army in the Korean War, discusses living conditions on Okinawa during World War II. He tells about mongooses being released on the island in an effort to control the snake population, and about guard duty. He also tells about how the Japanese infiltrated their camp, including coming to movies and getting food. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the repository.
relation: Veterans History Project collection, World War II and Korean War series

sourceResource.description: In this interview conducted by Rae Ann Kramer and Peggy Jemison in association with MIFA, they interview Alice Hanley. During this interview, they ask a series of questions pertaining to the neighborhood to get a understanding of the neighborhood dynamics of Hein Park that were at play during the time period between the 1910s - 1970s. These interviews were done in 1983 for the Everett R. Cook Oral History Collection on Civil Rights and were made available to the Crossroads to Freedom Digital Archive through a partnership with the Memphis Public Library. The transcripts represent what was said in the interview to the best of our ability. It is possible that some words, particularly names, have been misspelled. We have made no attempt to correct mistakes in grammar.

creator: Metro Government
sourceResource.description: An excerpt from a public meeting with former Nashville Mayor Beverly Briley conducted on April 5, 1968. Meeting held to discuss Vanderbilt student protest that took place on April 4. The main issue discussed was the calling of the National Guard. Mayor Briley felt that the Guard's presence might have increased tensions, but that it was justified in terms of what would happen if they were removed. Other issues mentioned were adult education programs and the possibility of legislation for equal housing and employment opportunity. The complete record of the meeting is available at the Metro Government Archives.

sourceResource.description: Audio files of Dickson County residents Howard Deal, Margaret Deal, and Earlie Deal recorded as part of the Tennessee State Parks Folklife Project. They describe opening their family sorghum mill in White Bluff in 1921. The step-by-step process of sorghum and molassas making is explained. The Deal's share family history and the challenges of running a sorghum mill. They also touch on field hollers or karo-ing, whistling, farming practices, livestock, and music.

sourceResource.description: An excerpt from an oral history interview with Nashville veteran James Carlew, conducted on 25 March 2004 by Larry Patterson as part of the Nashville Public Library's Veterans History Project. Carlew, who served in the Navy during World War II and in the Korean War, discusses the experience of escaping his tank after it had been hit by a mortar attack in Korea. He tells about ammunition exploding on the outside of the tank, making escape impossible through the top hatches, and having to exit the tank from the bottom. He also tells about the experience of fear during war. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the repository.
relation: Veterans History Project collection, World War II and Korean War series

The complete interview and transcript is available in the Special Collections Division.

sourceResource.description: An edited excerpt with transcript and photograph from an interview with Marion R. Jenkins and Sharon Y. Parrish, conducted on 15 September 2007 by their sister, Brenda P. Wynn, at the Nashville StoryCorps StoryBooth, located in the Nashville Room of the Nashville Public Library. The sisters share memories of their mother, Rosa L. Parrish, who died in 2006. This was the first interview conducted in the Nashville StoryCorps StoryBooth. The complete, un-edited interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division. These interviews were recorded by StoryCorps at the Nashville Public Library with the support of the Nashville Public Library Foundation and are provided courtesy of StoryCorps, a national initiative of Sound Portraits Productions to record and collect oral history interviews. www.storycorps.net

sourceResource.description: Excerpt from an oral history interview with Mary Margaret Lambert conducted on April 30, 2011 by Susannah Gibbons as part of the Flood 2010 Digital History Project. Away from Nashville at the time of the flood, Mary Margaret Lambert describes finding out about the death of her father Joseph Formosa Jr. and his wife Bessie Formosa, returning to Nashville, support from a neighbor who had lost everything. The complete interview is available in the Special Collections Division.
